There are six different possible mechanisms for viruses to cross the barriers:
Virus-carrying white blood cells squeeze through between the endothelial cells and deposit the viruses in the brain parenchyma [ 2]
Some viruses enter the vascular endothelial cells directly and then cross over into the CSF [ 2]
The open pores in the choroid plexus provide for direct entry of viruses into the CNS [ 2]
The BBB is not intact in the circumventricular organs, for example the area postrema and lamina terminalis. This forms an ideal site for viruses to enter the CNS [ 2]
The CNS lymphatic system as newly described by Louveau et al., in which the meningeal lymphatic vessels act as a reservoir for leukocytes, is a groundbreaking discovery [ 22] that may play an important role in future explanation of the pathogenesis of CNS infections [ 22, 23]
The barriers are disrupted as a direct cytotoxic effect of the pathogen and secondary inflammatory mediators [ 3].
